The composition of air
Air is a mixture of N2, O2, CO2, noble gases, water vapour and small amount of other gases
78% nitrogen - No simple test as it is very stable
21% oxygen - It relights glowing splint
0.03% carbon dioxide - It can turn limewater milky 
0.9% noble gases and other gases such as argon, neon etc. - no simple test as they are very stable

Separation of oxygen and nitrogen from air
Fraction distillation of liquefied air
The components of air are separated according to different boiling point

Process one: purification of air 
Very low temperature is used (80℃), CO2 and H2O become solid and are removed

Process two: liquefaction of air
The purified air is cooled down till -200℃

Process three: fractional distillation of liquefied air 
The substance with the lowest boiling point will boil off as gas first, and it will be collected at the highest and coldest part of the fractionating column

The use of nitrogen and oxygen
Oxygen: use as fuel in cutting and welding metals 
Nitrogen: food packing and produce ammonia
Carbon dioxide: make soft drinks 
Neon: make neon light 
Argon: used to fill up light bulb
Helium: use in airship
Chapter 3: The ocean
Composition of sea water
Sea water is a mixture containing water and dissolved substances
Most of the the dissolved substances are salts including sodium chloride, magnesium chloride, sodium sulphate, calcium chloride and other salts
The most abundant salt in sea water is as known as ‘common salt’ which is sodium chloride

Extraction of common salt from sea water
Filtration
To remove the insoluble substances from sea water
Filter paper must be used and only solvent and dissolved salts can pass through the small holes of the filter paper
The solid left on the filter paper is called residue. The liquid that passes through the filter paper is called distillate.

Evaporation
To obtain common salt from the filtered sea water
The filtered sea water is heated to dryness
Advantage:: Fast process
Disadvantages: crystal of salts are obtained 

Crystallization
To obtain crystal of common salt from sea water (to separate a solute from a solution)
Crystallization by slow cooling of hot saturated sea water
Heat the sea water to make it become saturated 
When the hot saturated sea water cool down slowly at room temperature, it can no longer hold all the dissolved salt
Hence, small amount of sodium chloride will separate out
Advantage: pure salts are obtained
Disadvantage: slow process
Crystallization by slow evaporation of sea water at room temperature
Sea water is allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature and becomes saturated
As evaporation continues, crystal of sodium chloride will separate out and will glow slowly in size
Advantage: pure salts are obtained
Disadvantage: slow process
After crystallization, the following steps are used to collect the crystals formed 
Filter the solution to collect the crystals on filter paper
Wash the crystal with small amount of cold distilled water
Dry the crystal with a filter paper


Isolation of pure water from sea water
Distillation using ‘Quickfit’ apparatus
Heat the sea water in the round-bottomed flask
Water will boil at 100℃ and change to steam. Then steam is condensed to become liquid, which is collected as the distillate
The salts in sea water are left, which is called the residue






Precaution in distillation
A few anti-bumping granules should be added in order to prevent bumping of sea water
The thermometer bulb should be placed near the entrance of the condenser in order to measure the temperature of the gas accurately
In the condenser, cold running water flow from the lower opening and leaves at the upper opening in order to have better cooling effect for the steam
The receiver adaptor should be kept above the liquid level in order to prevent backflow of distillate
The receiver adaptor should be removed before hearing is stopped in order to prevent backflow of distillate. Otherwise, the cold distillate will crack the hot glassware
It should not be a closed system, otherwise explosion will happen because of pressure build up

Test for the presence of cations in salt
Flame test
Moisten a clean platinum wire with concentrated hydrochloric acid
Dip the wire into crushed sample
Heat the sample strongly in a non-luminous flame
Observe the flame colour

Silver nitrate test

Test for the presence of water in a sample
Water turns anhydrous copper(II) sulphate from white to blue 
Water turns dry cobalt(II) chloride paper from blue to pink
Both of these two tests can only used to detect the presence of water but not to prove that the solution is pure water


Electrolysis of sea water
Electrolysis of sea water or brine produces sodium hydroxide, chlorine and hydrogen
2NaCl + 2H2O → H2 + Cl2 + 2NaOH 
Hydrogen can be used to make margarine and used as rocket fuel
Chlorine can be used to sterilize swimming pool and used to make solvent 
Sodium hydroxide can be used to make soap and used to make drain cleaner

Chapter 8: Covalent bonding
Molecules
Covalent bond is the strong and directional electrostatic force between shared electrons and two nuclei.


Dative covalent bond
Dative covalent bond is a covalent bond formed between two atoms where both electrons of the shared pair are contributed by the same atom


NH3 + H+ → NH4+
H+ does not have electrons in its outermost shell.
A lone pair of electrons on the N atom in NH3 is donated to H+ to form a dative covalent bond.

BF3 + NH3 → NH3BF3
The B atom in BF3 has three bond pairs of electrons.
A lone pair of electrons on the N atom in NH3 is donated to the B atom to form a dative covalent bond.

Formulae and names of covalent compounds

Formula mass is related to all substances

Van der Waals’ forces
Within a molecule, atoms are held together by strong covalent bond
Between molecules, molecules are held together by weak van der Waals’ forces only
Usually the larger the molecular size, the stronger is the van der Waals’ force between molecules


Chapter 9: Structures and properties of substances
Giant ionic structure
High melting and boiling point
Hard
Ionic compounds have a giant ionic structure.
Ions are held together by strong ionic bonds.
A lot of energy is needed to break the ionic bonds
Brittle
Ions are held together by strong ionic bonds.
Under an external force, relative movement of ions can bring ions of the same charge close to each other. This results in repulsion.
Most soluble in water
A strong attraction exists between ions in ionic compounds and water molecules.
Insoluble in organic solvent
The attraction between ions in ionic compounds and molecules of organic solvent is weaker than that of the ionic bonds between the ions.
Conduct electricity in molten state or in aqueous solution
There are mobile ions to conduct electricity when in molten state or in aqueous solution.

Giant metallic structure
High melting and boiling point
Strong & hard
Metal has a giant metallic structure.
Metal ions and delocalized electrons are held together by strong metallic bonds.
A lot of energy is needed to break the metallic bonds.
Alkali metals are weak and soft
The positive charge carried by alkali metal is smaller than alkaline earth metal.
As a result, the metallic bonds in alkali metal are weaker.
High density
Metal ions are packed closely in the structures of metals.
Alkali metals have a lower density
The alkali metal ions only have 1+ charge, so their metallic bonds are relatively weaker. The metal ions are only loosely packed in the lattice.
Insoluble in any solvent
Metal ions and delocalized electrons are held together by strong metallic bonds.
Metal ions won’t be attracted by water molecules or any solvent molecules.
Alkali metal will react instead of dissolving in water
All alkali metal and some alkaline earth metal can react with water to form solutions, but not dissolve in water.
Good conductors of electricity
Metal has delocalized electrons.
Good conductors of heat
The delocalized electrons gain heat and move faster.
Energy is transferred from the hot side to the cool side by the collision of delocalized electrons.
Malleable and ductile
Metal ions and delocalized electrons are held together by strong metallic bonds.
Under an external force, layers of metal ions slide over one another and form new metallic bonds.



Simple molecular structure
Low melting and boiling point
Soft but brittle
Molecules have a simple molecular structure.
The molecules are held together by weak van der Waals’ forces.
Little energy is needed to break the weak forces.
Non-conductors of electricity
Molecules don't contain any mobile ions or delocalized electrons.
However, some acid would conduct electricity when dissolved in water (ionization).
Slightly soluble/insoluble in water
The attraction between molecules and water molecules is weaker than the attraction between water molecules.
However, some acids are very soluble in water.
Soluble in organic solvent
Molecules of organic solvents are held together by weak attractive forces which are similar to the attractions between molecules.

Giant covalent structure
Very high melting and boiling point
Very hard
Insoluble in any solvent
Substance has a giant covalent structure.
Atoms are held together by strong covalent bonds.
A lot of energy is needed to break the covalent bonds.
Graphite is brittle	
The layers of carbon are held together by weak van der Waals’ forces.
Under a force, the layers can slide over each other.
Cannot conduct electricity
There are no mobile ions or delocalized electrons.
Graphite does conduct electricity
It contains delocalized electrons.

Chapter 13: Corrosion of metals and their protection
Corrosion of metals
The more reactive the metal, the more rapidly it corrodes.

Corrosion of iron (rusting)
Rusting requires both oxygen and water.
Fe(s) → Fe2+(aq) + 2e-
O2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 4e- → 4OH-(aq)
4Fe(s) + 3O2(g) +2nH2O(l) → 2Fe2O3．nH2O(s)
The rust formed is loosely attached to the iron surface, which falls off easily.

Investigating rusting of iron using rust indicator
Potassium hexacyanoferrate(III), K3[Fe(CN)6] will detect the presence of Fe2+(aq) and turn it to blue.
Phenolphthalein will detect the presence of OH-(aq) and turn it to pink.
Sodium chloride will increase the electrical conductivity which relates to the delocalized electrons and makes corrosion occur more quickly.

Factors that speed up rusting
Presence of acidic substance (OH- will reduce the corrosion rate)
Presence of soluble ionic compound
High temperature
Attachment of less reactive metals to iron
Scratched, bent or sharp area of an iron object
These kinds of factors are in order to speed up the formation of Fe2+(aq).

Sacrificial protection
A more reactive metal will lose electrons more readily than iron, preventing iron from losing electrons to form Fe2+(aq).
Galvanized iron (zinc coating)
Zinc is more reactive than iron, zinc will lose electrons more readily than iron when zinc coating is partly scratched.
Zinc ions are poisonous. (Not used in food cans)
Attaching zinc blocks to ship hulls
Zinc blocks need to be replaced once it has completely corroded.
Connecting magnesium blocks to underground pipelines
Magnesium blocks need to be replaced from time to time.
Cathodic protection
The negative terminal of a battery provides electrons to the iron object, preventing it from losing electrons to form Fe2+(aq).

Corrosion resistance of aluminium
Protective oxide layer on aluminium
A thin layer of aluminium oxide forms on the aluminium surface, when it is exposed to air.
4Al(s) + 3O2(g) → 2Al2O3(s)
The oxide layer is impermeable to water and oxygen and protects the aluminium from further corrosion.
Thickening the protective oxide layer on aluminium
Anodization

Cathode(-): Aluminium sheet or graphite
Electrolyte: Dilute sulphuric acid

Aluminium objects become more corrosion resistant.
Hardness of aluminium objects increases.
Anodized aluminium can be dyed easily to give attractive colours.
The strength of an aluminium object cannot be enhanced by anodization.

Chapter 17: Strength of acids and alkalis
Strong acids/alkalis and weak acids/alkalis
The strength of acids is related to their extent of ionization in water.

A strong acid is an acid which completely ionizes in water to give H+ ions.
Hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, sulphuric acid
A weak acid is an acid which partially ionizes in water to give H+ ions.
Ethanoic acid, carbonic acid, sulphurous acid, phosphoric acid
A strong alkali is an alkali which completely dissociates in water to give hydroxide ions.
Sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide
A weak alkali is an alkali which partially ionizes in water to give hydroxide ions.
Ammonia

Do 2 acids have the same pH value?
Compare strength
Compare basicity
Compare H+ concentration
Compare pH

Comparing the strength of strong acid/alkali and weak acid/alkali of the same concentration
A strong acid has a lower pH than a weak acid of the same molarity.
A strong acid has a higher electrical conductivity than a weak acid of the same molarity
A strong acid has a higher reaction rate than a weak acid of the same molarity.
Note: the amount of products is the same.
A strong alkali has a higher pH than a weak alkali of the same molarity.
A strong alkali has a higher electrical conductivity than a weak alkali of the same molarity.

Strength and concentration of of acids/alkalis
There is no relation between strength and concentration of acids/alkalis.

Back titration calculation steps
Calculate acid/alkali added at start
Calculate leftover acid/alkali from titration results
Start – leftover = acid/alkali reacted with solid

Calculate mass and percentage by mass


Typical back titration question:
3.00 g of a marble sample is added to 50.0 cm3 of 1.20 M hydrochloric acid. The excess acid requires 28.80 cm3 of 0.500 M sodium hydroxide solution for complete reaction. Calculate the percentage by mass of calcium carbonate in the marble sample. (Assume that all other substances in the marble sample react with neither hydrochloric acid nor sodium hydroxide solution.) (Relative atomic masses: C = 12.0, O = 16.0, Ca = 40.1)

Question analysis: After adding marble to excess HCl, HCl will react with marble and the volume will decrease. To calculate the mass of marble, titrate the solution formed with NaOH to measure the amount of HCl leftover, since only HCl reacts with NaOH. After that, subtract the initial volume from the final volume and find the amount of HCl used. Finally, calculate the mass and % by mass of CaCO3 by mole ratio.

CaCO3(s) + 2HCl(aq) → CaCl2(aq) + H2O(l) + CO2(g)
HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → H2O(l) + NaCl(aq)
HCl added at the start = 50.0/1000 × 1.20 = 0.06 mol
Mol of NaOH of titration = 28.80 / 1000 × 0.500 = 0.0144 mol
Mole ratio = 1 : 1
Mole of leftover HCl = 0.0144 × 1 = 0.0144 mol
Mol of HCl reacted with CaCO3 = 0.06 - 0.0144 = 0.0456 mol
According to mole ratio, Mol of CaCO3 = 0.0456 ÷ 2 = 0.0228 mol
Mass of CaCO3 = 0.0228 × (40.1 + 12.0 + 16.0 × 3) = 2.28228 g
% by mass of CaCO3 = 2.28228 ÷ 3.00 × 100% = 76%

The physical properties of straight-chain alkanes change gradually along the homologous series.

All alkanes are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents(hexane, 1,1,1-trichloromethane). All liquid alkanes are less dense than water and thus float on water.

Alkanes are unreactive because the C-C and C-H bonds are strong and difficult to break.
All alkanes have similar chemical properties. Higher members of alkanes usually react more slowly than lower members.

With sufficient supply of oxygen, complete combustion occurs
Reaction with halogens(Substitution reaction)
In the presence of sunlight/UV light/heat, alkane reacts with halogens(dissolved in an organic solvent), the orange/brown bromine solution decolourised slowly and steamy fumes are produced. 
The reaction between them is a substitution reaction.
Chemical equations(e.g. Methane + chlorine dissolved in CH3CCl3):
CH4 + Cl2 → CH3Cl + HCl
CH3 + Cl2 → CH2Cl2 + HCl
CH2Cl2 + Cl2 → CHCl3 + HCl
CHCl3 + Cl2 → CCl4 + HCl
This is a chain reaction which is uncontrollable
A mixture of products will be produced, including CH3Cl, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4, HCl.
If Cl2 is in excess, CCl4 will be the major product.
If CH4 is in excess, CH3Cl will be the major product.
Cl2 reacts faster with methane than Br2 does, as reactivity of halogen decreases down the group

Remark:
Energy(light or heat) must be supplied for the reaction to take place. It is used to break the strong Br-Br bond, in order to form bromine free radical(Br •) to initiate the reaction.
A free radical is an atom or a group of atoms with at least one unpaired electron. It is highly reactive and exists only momentarily because the outermost electron shell of the chlorine radicals doesn’t have a stable octet structure.
We usually use Br2 in organic solvent or bromine water (Br2(aq)), because pure bromine liquid is very toxic.


Use electron diagram to illustrate monosubstitution of methane with chlorine
Initiation > Propagation > Termination
Initiation
The energy supplied by UV light breaks the Cl-Cl bonds in chlorine molecules to form chlorine free radicals.
Cl2 → light → 2Cl•
Propagation 
Each chlorine radical combines with a hydrogen atom from a methane molecule to form a methyl radical and a hydrogen chloride molecule.
CH4 + Cl• → CH3• + HCl
Some of the methyl radicals then combine with chlorine atoms from other chlorine molecules to form chloromethane molecules and chlorine radicals.
CH3• + Cl2 → CH3Cl + Cl3•
Termination 
Two chlorine radicals combine to form a chlorine molecule.
2Cl• → Cl2
A methyl radical combines with a chlorine radical to form a chloromethane molecule.
CH3• + Cl• → CH3Cl
Two methyl radicals combine to form an ethane molecule.
2CH3• → CH3CH3
The products formed from the monosubstitution of methane with chlorine: CH3Cl, CH3CH3 and HCl

Q1: Explain why the shape of a CCl4 molecule is similar to that of a CH4 molecule.

Chapter 25: Polarity of bond and molecule
Electronegativity of an atom
The electronegativity of an atom refers to the power of the atom in a molecule to attract bonding electrons to itself.
The most electronegativity element is fluorine.(F > O > Cl > N)
The least electronegativity element is francium.
The noble gases have no electronegativity values because they don’t form covalent bonds.

Polarity of bond
Non-polar covalent bond
Covalent bond formed between two same atoms(same electronegativity).
The bonding electrons are equally shared between the bonded atoms.
Polar covalent bond
Covalent bond formed between two different atoms(different electronegativities).
The bonding electrons aren’t equally shared between the atoms.
Less electronegativity → partial positive charge(ẟ+)
More electronegativity → partial negative charge(ẟ–)

Electronegativity difference and bond polarity
The greater the electronegativity difference, the more polar the bond is.

Polarity of molecule
Polar molecules
e.g. HF, H2O, NH3, CHCl3
Non-polar molecules
e.g. CO2, BF3, CH4, PCl5, SF6

Typical question of polarity of molecules
Q: Explain why a NCl3 molecule is polar while a BCl3 molecule is non-polar.
A NCl3 molecule has a trigonal pyramidal shape. The polarity of the N–Cl bonds don’t cancel out each other, so NCl3 molecule is polar.
A BCl3 molecule has a trigonal planar shape. The polarity of the B–Cl bonds cancel out each other, so BCl3 molecule is non-polar.

Effect of charged rod on polar and non-polar liquids
If the jet is deflected towards the rod, the liquid contains polar molecules.
If the jet shows no deflection, it contains only non-polar molecules.
If a positively/negatively charged rod is used, the negative/positive ends of the polar molecules are attracted to the rod.
Chapter 26: Intermolecular forces

Intermolecular forces
The electrostatic attractions between molecules are called intermolecular forces.
Van der Waals’ forces / hydrogen bond
They’re much weaker than ionic bonds and covalent bonds.

Van der Waals’ force
It exists between all molecules, no matter polar or not.
Van der Waals’ forces in polar molecules
e.g. HCl molecule
The positive end of an HCl molecule will be attracted to the negative end of another HCl molecule.
Van der Waals’ force in non-polar molecules(Dispersion forces)
e.g. N2 molecule
The electrons in the molecule are in constant motion. At any given instant of time, the electron distribution may be uneven. The side with more electrons has a partial negative charge and the other side has a partial positive charge.

Factors affecting the strength of van der Waals’ forces
Molecular size
Number of electrons, change of the uneven distribution of electrons, strength of van der Waals’ forces and boiling point increase. 
(F2→Cl2→Br2→I2) According to the order, as the molecular size of the molecules increases, the van der Waals’ forces between molecules become stronger.
Although relative atomic mass is proportional to size, don’t compare their size while they’re containing the similar relative atomic masses.
Molecular shape 
When the area of contact between molecules increases, the strength of van der Waals’ forces and boiling point increases.
e.g. pentane(C5H12) v.s. dimethylpropane(C5H12)
Pentane molecules are rod-shaped while dimethylpropane molecules are spherical in shape. Pentane has a greater area of contact between molecules, the van der Waals’ forces between molecules are stronger than those between dimethylpropane molecules.
Molecular polarity
The strength of van der Waals’ forces increases when the molecules are more polar.
e.g. cis-1,2-dichloroethene(polar) v.s. trans-1,2-dichloroethene(non-polar)
Cis-1,2-dichloroethene is polar while trans-1,2-dichloroethene is non-polar. The van der Waals’ forces between cis-1,2-dichloroethene molecules are stronger than those between trans-1,2-dichloroethene molecules.

Hydrogen bonding
Evidence of hydrogen bonding
NH3, H2O and HF have exceptionally high boiling points.
Formation of hydrogen bonding
Hydrogen bond is the electrostatic force between a partially positively charged H atom and the lone pair of electrons of a highly electronegative atom(N, O, F) of another molecule.







Effect of hydrogen bonding on physical properties of water and ethanol
Water
High boiling point
There is extensive hydrogen bonding between water molecules. A lot of energy is needed to overcome the hydrogen bonds between water molecules.
High surface tension
H2O molecules are held together by extensive hydrogen bonds.
High viscosity
H2O molecules are held together by extensive hydrogen bonds. H2O molecules cannot move past one another easily.
Ethanol(CH3CH2OH)
Relatively high boiling point
Ethanol molecules are held together by extensive hydrogen bonds. Hence, a large amount of energy is needed to overcome the hydrogen bonds between ethanol molecules.
High viscosity
Ethanol molecules are held together by extensive hydrogen bonds.
Soluble in water
As ethanol has hydroxyl group(–OH), so it can form hydrogen bonds with H2O molecules.

Comparing the strengths of van der Waals’ forces, hydrogen bonding and covalent bonding
Hydrogen bond is stronger than van der Waals’ force, but much weaker than covalent bond.
The stronger the intermolecular focus in the liquid, the longer time it takes the liquid to evaporate.

Chapter 27: Structures and properties of ice

Properties of ice
Density
Ice has a lower density than liquid water.
In ice, each water molecule can form four hydrogen bonds with four neighbouring water molecules tetrahedrally. The tetrahedral arrangement of water molecules repeats to form an open structure of ice. When ice melts, water molecules have relative motions and this makes the open structure collapse. Hence, water molecules are packed more closely. As a result, ice is less dense than liquid water.
Melting point
Ice has a relatively high melting point compared with substances of similar relative atomic mass.
In ice, water molecules are held together by extensive and relatively strong hydrogen bonds. When ice melts, a lot of energy is needed to overcome a certain amount of hydrogen bonds between water molecules.

Chapter 33: Energy changes in chemical reactions

Law of conservation of energy
Energy cannot be created or destroyed. Energy can be transferred from one form to another. The total amount of energy remains constant.

Enthalpy change of a reaction
Heat change at constant pressure = change in internal energy + work done on surroundings
= enthalpy change of the reaction

Enthalpy and enthalpy change
All substances have a certain enthalpy (heat content) which is an indication of the energy content.
Enthalpy change of a reaction (ΔH) = the heat change at constant pressure 
= Total enthalpy of products (Hp) - Total enthalpy of reactants (Hr) 

Exothermic and endothermic reactions in terms of enthalpy change
Exothermic reaction (ΔH = -ve)
Combustion reactions, neutralization reactions, precipitation reactions, displacement reaction, reaction between calcium oxide (quicklime) and water & adding conc. H2SO4 in water
Instant hot pack (CaO / CaCl2 + H2O) & hand warmer (Fe + O2)
Endothermic reaction (ΔH = +ve)
Cracking, thermal decomposition, electrolysis, photosynthesis & heating blue hydrated CuSO4 crystals
Instant cold pack (Ammonium nitrate + water)

Exothermic and endothermic reactions in term of breaking and forming of chemical bonds
Breaking of bonds takes in energy → endothermic process
Forming of bonds gives out energy → exothermic process
The reaction between X and Y is an exothermic/ endothermic reaction. It is because the total energy absorbed in the bond breaking process is smaller/ larger than the total energy released in the bond forming process.
Chapter 34: Standard enthalpy change of reactions

Standard enthalpy changes and thermochemical equation
A. Standard enthalpy changes and thermochemical equation
Standard enthalpy change of reaction is the enthalpy change of reaction measured under the standard conditions
Pressure: 1 atm
Temperature: 25℃
State: All substances involved are in standard states (the most stable form e.g. graphite  X diamond)
Concentration of solution: 1M
B. Thermochemical equation
MUST WRITE PHYSICAL STATE AND ENTHALPY CHANGE
A balanced chemical equation with physical states and enthalpy change.

Standard enthalpy change of combustion
The enthalpy change when 1 mole of the substance is completely burnt in oxygen under standard conditions.
Coefficient of the substance to be burnt must be 1.
Enthalpy change must be negative, as combustion is an exothermic reaction.

Determination of enthalpy change of combustion using simple calorimetric methods
All the heat released is assumed to be absorbed by the water.
Enthalpy change of combustion = ((mcΔT) / number of moles of the substance burnt) x -1

Standard enthalpy change of neutralization
The enthalpy change when 1 mole of water is produced from neutralization between an acid and an alkali under standard conditions.
Coefficient of water must be 1.
Enthalpy change must be negative, as neutralization is an exothermic reaction.

Determination of enthalpy changes of neutralization using simple calorimetric methods
Expanded polystyrene cup can reduce the heat loss to the surroundings.
The cotton wool packed inside the cup can further minimize the heat loss to the surroundings.
A stirrer is used to ensure that the two solutions are mixed well.
Enthalpy change of combustion = ((mcΔT) / number of moles of water formed) x -1

Standard enthalpy change of formation
The enthalpy change when 1 mole of the substance forms from its constituent elements in their standard states under standard conditions.
Coefficient of the substance formed must be 1.
Enthalpy change can be negative, positive or zero.
Enthalpy change of all elements in their standard states are zero.

Sources of error in determining the enthalpy change from simple calorimetric methods
There was heat loss to the surroundings caused by conduction and convection.
The experiment wasn’t done under standard conditions.
The heat capacities of the expanded polystyrene cup/ thermometer etc. weren’t taken into account.

Determination of enthalpy change of formation (why not simple calorimetric methods)
Some reactions proceed too slowly under standard conditions
Some formation reactions are highly exothermic and cannot be safely carried out.
Side reactions may lead to the formation of side products.

Hess’s Law
The total enthalpy change of a chemical reaction is independent of the pathway between initial and final states.

Calculating the standard enthalpy change of a reaction from standard enthalpy changes of formation

Enthalpy change = products – reactants

Calculating standard enthalpy change of combustion

Enthalpy change = reactants – products

Rate of reaction
Fast reaction: Test for H2(g) and O2(g), displacement reaction or precipitation etc.
Moderate rate: Mg reacts with dilute H2SO4 
Slow rate: Rusting
Rate of reaction = change in concentration of a reactant or product / time
The rate of reaction must be positive.

Concentration-time graph
Curve
Meaning
The curve starts from the origin
At t = 0, no product is formed.
The curve is the steepest at t = 0 /
The slope of tangent is the largest
The reaction rate at the beginning/the initial rate is the highest.
The curve becomes less steep with time and becomes horizontal finally
The reaction rate decreases with time and becomes zero finally.
The point that the curve become horizontal
The reaction stops. No more products form.


Average rate of reaction
Rate of reaction = change in concentration of a reactant or product / delta time

Instantaneous rate of reaction
It can be determined by finding the slope of the tangent to the curve at that instant.

Initial rate of reaction
Initial rate is the instantaneous rate of a reaction at time t = 0.

Methods of following the progress of a chemical reaction
By measuring the volume of hydrogen gas produced at regular time intervals. (gas syringe)
By measuring the change in pressure of the reaction system at regular time intervals (pressure sensor and data-logger)
Data-logger can collect and store data over very short time intervals
Experimental data can be presented in the form of graph immediately
By measuring the change in mass of the reaction mixture at regular time intervals. (electronic balance)
Cotton wool is used to allow the gas to escape but prevent the acid from splashing out.
Gaseous products with very low density are not suitable for this reaction.
By messing the change in colour intensity of the reaction mixture at regular time intervals (colorimeter)
The reaction must involve only one coloured reactant or product.
Titrimetric analysis
At regular time intervals, withdraw small portions of the reaction mixture using a pipette.
Quench the reaction in the small portions by pouring them into a large amount of ice-cold distilled water.
Cooling the reaction mixture in ice rapidly
Diluting the reaction mixture with a large volume of ice-cold water
Titrate the quenched portions against standard acid/alkalis using phenolphthalein
Bad: Continuous monitoring of the progress of the reaction is impossible or titrimetric analysis takes time and this cannot be used for rapid reactions.

Chapter 37: Factors affecting rate of reaction

Four factors

Chapter 39: Dynamic equilibrium

H2(g) + I2(g) ⇌ 2HI(g)
At the start, the rate of forward reaction is the highest, as the concentration of H2 and I2 are the highest.
Meanwhile, the rate of the backward reaction is zero as there is no HI.
The colour intensity of the reaction mixture is the highest.

As the reaction proceeds, the rate of the forward reaction decreases as the concentration of H2 and I2 decreases.
Meanwhile, the rate of the backward reaction increases as the concentration of HI increases.
The colour intensity of the reaction mixture decreases.

Eventually, when dynamic equilibrium is reached, the rates of forward and backward reaction are equal and the concentration of H2, I2 and HI remain unchanged.
No further change in colour intensity.

Summary
At dynamic equilibrium the rate of forward reaction and the rate of backward reaction becomes equal.
At dynamic equilibrium, the concentration of all reactants and products remain unchanged. Hence, there is no observable change of the reaction mixture.
Dynamic equilibrium can be reached from either the forward or the backward direction of the reversible reaction. 
Dynamic equilibrium can only be established in a closed system.


Chapter 40: Equilibrium constant

The equilibrium constant, Kc, is a constant value for a reaction at equilibrium at a given temperature, no matter what the initial concentrations of the reactions or products are.
Temperature change = equilibrium constant change 

Homogeneous equilibrium
An equilibrium system in which all the reactants and products are in the same phrase.
Heterogeneous equilibrium
An equilibrium system in which two or more phases are present.
Different phases don’t necessarily mean different physical states. (oil and water)
The ‘concentration’ of pure solids and pure liquids in heterogeneous equilibrium are constant. They do not appear in the expression of Kc

What does an equilibrium constant tell us ?!
The magnitude of Kc indicates the extent of a chemical equation at equilibrium, but not the rate of the reaction.
Chapter 41: The effect of changes in concentration, pressure and temperature on chemical equilibria

Equilibrium position
If Kc is large, the equilibrium position shifts to the right side. The product concentrations at equilibrium are high.
If Kc is small, the equilibrium position shifts to the left side. The reactant concentrations at equilibrium are high.

The effect of change in concentration on chemical equilibria
Fe3+(aq) + SCN-(aq) ←→ FeSCN2+(aq)
iron(III) ion is yellow while thiocyanatoiron(III) ion is dark red
Thus, the color of equilibrium mixture is orange-yellow
Example:
When Fe3+(aq)/SCN-(aq) is added,
the concentration of Fe3+(aq)/SCN-(aq) increases
the equilibrium position shifts to the right to consume some of it 
the forward reaction rate is higher than the backward reaction rate

Predicting the direction of shift in the equilibrium position from the reaction quotient, Qc
Reaction quotient is calculated from concentrations at any particular moment, not necessarily at equilibrium
Qc has the same unit of Kc
Qc < Kc: shifts to the right
Qc = Kc: no change
Qc > Kc: shifts to the left

The effect of change in pressure or volume on chemical equilibria
Example:
4 moles of gas ←→ 2 moles of gas 
The system responds by reducing the pressure 
As the no. of moles of gases on reactant side is larger than that on product side
The equilibrium position will shift to the right to reduce the no. of mole of gas and hence reduce the pressure
the forward reaction rate is higher than the backward reaction rate
Equilibrium position only changes when there are different numbers of moles of gas on reactant and product side.
Pressure doesn’t affect the concentrations of solids and liquids

The effect of change in temperature on chemical equilibria
When temperature changes, reaction rate, equilibrium constant and equilibrium position will be affected.
Both forward and backward reaction rate increase, but to different extents.
equilibrium can be reached more rapidly
Example:
N2O4(g) ←→ 2NO2(g) 	ΔH = +58 kJ mol-1
As the forward reaction is endothermic,
when temperature increases the equilibrium position shifts to the right, so Kc increases.

Chapter 43: Isomerism

Isomerism
Isomers are different compounds with the same molecular formula but different structures or different arrangements of atoms in space.

Structural isomerism
Structural isomerism occurs when there are two or more compounds with the same molecular formula but different orders of linkage of atoms.
Chain isomerism
Chain isomers have the same functional group, but different carbon skeletons.
They have similar chemical properties, but different physical properties.
#Alkanes have no functional group.
Position isomerism
Position isomers have the same carbon skeleton and functional group.
They differ only in the position of the functional group.
They have similar chemical properties as they have the same functional group, but different physical properties. (e.g. CH2=CHCH2CH3 & CH3CH=CHCH3)
Functional group isomerism
Functional group isomers have the same molecular formula but different functional groups.
They have totally different physical and chemical properties as their functional groups are different.

Stereoisomerism
Stereoisomerism occurs when there are compounds in which atoms are joined in the same order but have a different spatial arrangement.
Cis-trans isomerism
Cis-trans isomerism occurs when there are stereoisomers resulting from restricted rotation about carbon-carbon double bonds.
#Carbon-carbon single bonds can rotate freely. Thus, often they would have the same spatial arrangement of atoms. (same molecules).
Cis-trans isomerism is found only in alkenes that have two different atoms or groups of atoms attached to each doubly-bonded carbon atom.
Cis-isomers
Trans-isomers
The same atoms/group of atoms are on the same sider of the double bond.
The same atoms/group of atoms are on the opposite side of the double bond.

Physical properties
Boiling point (depends on strength of intermolecular forces with polarity)
Melting point (mainly depends on packing efficiency with the symmetrical structure)

Enantiomerism
Enantiomerism occurs when there are two stereoisomers that are mirror images of one another but are not superimposable.

Achiral molecule (symmetric)
Chiral molecule (asymmetric)
- The C atom is attached to 4 atoms or groups of atoms, but at least 2 attached atoms/groups of atoms are the same.
- Achiral molecule has at least one plane of symmetry.
- Achiral molecule is superimposable on its mirror image.
- The C atom is attached to 4 different atoms or groups of atoms, which is called the chiral center.
- Chiral molecules have no plane of symmetry.
- Chiral molecule is not superimposable in its mirror image.
- Chiral molecules have enantiomers.


Chemical properties
Enantiomers have the same chemical properties except the reaction with another chiral molecule.
Physical properties
Enantiomers have very similar (identical) physical properties. They have the same boiling point, melting point, density etc.
The only difference is that they have different interactions on place-polarized light.
Two enantiomers can rotate the place of polarization of a beam of plane polarized light to opposite directions to the same extent
(+)-isomer: rotate the plane of polarization in clockwise direction..
(-)-isomer: rotate the plane of polarization in an anticlockwise direction.
Chiral molecules are always said to be optical active. This property is called optical activity.
The optical activity can be measured by using a polarimeter.

Chapter 47: Periodic variation in physical properties of the elements from Li to Ar

Elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic number and in groups and periods, in the modern Periodic Table.

Periodic variations in structure and bonding across periods 2 and 3
Metals → Semi-metals → non-metals
The metallic character of elements generally decreases.
The bonding of elements changes from metallic bonds to covalent bonds.
The structure of elements changes from giant metallic structures to giant covalent structures, and eventually to simple molecular structures.
B and Si are semi-metals which have giant covalent structures.

Interpreting the variation in melting point of elements across a period
Across a period, the melting point of elements rises from Group I to a maximum in Group IV. Then it drops sharply to Group V, and reaches a minimum in Group 0
Across period 2 (Li → Be) & period 3 (Na → Al)
They all have giant metallic structures.
The number of delocalized electrons participating in metallic bond formation increases.
The strength of metallic bonds increases. Hence the melting point increases.
B, C and Si have very high melting points
They all have giant covalent structures.
Atoms are held together by strong covalent bonds in their structures.
Across period 2 (N → Ne) & period 3 (P → Ar)
They all have simple molecular structures.
Period 2: Molecular size: N2 > O2 > F2 > Ne
Period 3: Molecular size: S8 > P4 > Cl2 > Ar
The strength of van der Waals’ forces increases as the molecular size increases.
Therefore, the melting points also increase.
Melting point: N2 > O2, but boiling point: O2 > N2 (fractional distillation of liquified air)

Interpreting the variation in electrical conductivity of elements across a period
Across period 2 (Li → Be) & period 3 (Na → Al)
They all have giant metallic structures.
As the number of delocalized electrons increases, the electrical conductivity increases.
C(diamond) and silicon don’t conduct electricity
All of their outermost shell electrons are used for the formation of covalent bonds, so there are no delocalized electrons in their structures.
In graphite, only three of its four outermost shell electrons in each carbon atom are sussed for forming covalent bonds, leaving one electron available for delocalization. So graphite conducts electricity.
Silicon is a semi-metal. At higher temperatures, more electrons gain energy and become delocalized. It will become a good conductor of electricity in that specific condition.
Across period 2 (N → Ne) & period 3 (P → Ar) 
They are non-conductors of electricity.
They all have simple molecular structures, their molecules have no delocalized electrons.
